ratings.comment: Slides are unorganized and information is scattered

This class is meant to be a blowoff biological sciences class. It is what it is. The class is relatively simple/boring, but it is definitely an easy A, just show up. Weekly quizzes with one test at the end. He is one of 3 professors, and arguably the second best of the three. Not very exciting, but you do learn a bit about current issues.

His lectures can go a bit fast, and he tends to go on tangents that can be really interesting but are usually not relevant to the exam material. He posts audio recordings of the lectures and the slides, but it's way more helpful to just go to class.

He was very helpful for me. I haven't historically good at genetics, so after I was abused by the first test, I made it a priority to go talk to him before each test during office hours. He was very helpful during that time, answered my questions, and went over entire class lessons that I was foggy about. and my grade made a good recovery. (AB)

People hate on Laughon a lot, but compared to Engels, he was an angel. I'll admit, he goes off on tangents and lecture can get confusing, but his exams are EXTREMELY fair. He gives you practice exams that are almost exactly the same as the actual exams, so if you study properly they're not bad. Textbook is very helpful. Overall, I liked him.

I don't know why people complain so much about him, I really liked him. He was very straight forward during his lectures and I actually thought he went really slowly at times. I got an AB on his exam and didn't really study for it, but I think if I had done some of the more complicated homework question it would have been an A.

I don't know why everyone hates on Laughon as a professor for this class. 466 seems to set you up for failure, especially if you have Engels as your other prof but Laughon really seems to want to be there and teach you the material. His exams accurately reflected what was taught in lecture/ what was on the practice exam. If you study you'll get it.

He wasn't great, but wasn't terrible either.  DO textbook readings they will really help you prepare for the exam. Make sure if he posts practice exams to understand everything on it. Exams are difficult but fair; Averages were around a 70% on his exams compared to 50% averages with Professor Engels.

Anyone who needs to take this class knows 466 will be difficult no matter what, but he's definitely a difficult prof. He also seems a little scatter-brained while presenting. He presents a slide but rambles, making it difficult to take notes or to glean anything from the slides themselves. He was, at least, willing to answer questions after class.

I'll start by saying I finished my Junior year at Madison with a 3.9 GPA. This class was indescribably hard, frustrating, and made me feel as though I was the most unequipped student there is. Even with TA's help I still felt behind and lost. I finished with a C. I don't blame this on my own ill sense but instead on this "educator's." Worst class.

In the immortal words of Keyshawn Johsnon, "C'mon Man!" I came in expecting 466 to be an extremely hard class, but this guy takes it to another level. You better spend at least 6 hours per lecture if you even want to sniff an A. He does more molecular biology on one test than an entire semester's worth of that type of material. Nice guy, bad Prof.

Not a very interesting lecturer and sometimes mumbles. His lectures and slides are also all over the place, especially during the first part of genetics.  But since they do put lecture videos up, it's not as bad and more comprehensible.

His tests are so unrelated to what he says in class. He mumbles and his slides contain no information besides pictures. You for sure will not be able to pay attention in class. Overall, this class blows in general, they curve it to a low BCC. I am a premed student who has never got lower than a B and I am getting a BC or C. Worst class I've taken

A nice guy but lectures are very unorganized.  His slides are all pictures and he jumps all over the place, assuming we have background on all the topics.  He says things like "this is a tough concept so I won't explain it, you'll have to go home and learn it."  Outrageous amount of in-depth details we're expected to know. Avoid taking his section.
Lectures are disorienting. I've never used this site but feel compelled to warn students to avoid this guy. I really hoped to master this subject matter too....

He's a really nice guy, but he just rambles on about the material. It's really hard to pay attention to the lectures. The main problem is that the lecture slides are everywhere. The topics he covers aren't coherent and spread out into different lectures in different orders.

Seems like a nice guy, but this class was such a struggle. I'm a pre-med student that usually gets ABs or above and got a low B in this class. The amount of information you need to know for exams is ridiculous. TAs were helpful, but even they struggled with the material. Unless you have to take this class for your major, don't do it.

A slide with a picture comes up and he just sits there on it for 5 minutes and talks about everything he knows. No pattern or organization.. not realizing that he needs to present some things before others... teaching by example before we even understand the principle of what he is talking about. He really destroys a very interesting subject.

Laughon should not be allowed to teach this class.  If there is anyway students could take action and remove him from teaching GEN466 I would do so and never feel more passionate about it.  Lecture will most certainly confuse you more than help you.

One of the worst profs I have ever had & for a course that I need/want to know well for my future. He doesn't speak in full/coherent sentences and mumbles. Every lecture is extremely dense, slides are mostly pictures with no detail. This course is extremely important to all of bio and he should not be allowed to teach it in any way. Avoid him
If saving the entire human race depended on this man constructing a single coherent sentence, we would all perish.

This guy shouldn't be allowed to teach. His slides are dense and he doesn't explain them well at all. Exams were very difficult and there is no good way to study for them. TAs even struggled with the material. He forgets to record lecture sometimes, so go to class. Don't take genetics with Laughon or Engels or you'll regret it.

I made this account solely to tell people to avoid this man. He is hands down the worst professor I have ever had. It is near impossible to get above a B in this class. I have never gotten below a B and I am on the C D border. Going to class does not help. Lecture slides are useless and vague, he mumbles more than he talks and makes test impossible

Easily the worst professor I have ever had. Mumbles the entire lecture and doesn't finish his sentences. Has said things like "this is difficult, you'll have to figure it out for yourself". Slides are mostly pictures and has no explanation of complicated topics. Exams are super specific and there's really no good way to prepare for them.

Requires you to know a ton of information, slides are confusing and poorly organized. You'll definitely be asked to reproduce diagrams on exams. I went to his office hours a couple times and he's much more helpful then, I'd highly recommend going if you're confused.
Terrible professor. He has so much information on every slide, and he expects you to know every detail of every slide for the exam. He mumbles and goes way too fast. At least the curve is generous.

He will definitely challenge you. He covered more molecular biology in half a semester than we did in one semester of Biochemistry. He definitely knows almost everything about molecular biology and teaches from current research papers in addition to the textbook. Pay attention well and take good notes in class...he mumbles a lot.

Went to one class with him, and could not keep up with his lecture at all.  Found it much easier to skip class and go over his slides on my own, googling every topic.  Vocab list for the last exam was 800 words, most not in textbook or lecture slides.  Must memorize most diagrams on lecture slides, many questions ask you to draw them on tests.

literally the worst teacher I have had thus far at UW-Madison. i knew just about everything on each of his slides (which he requires you to know the tiniest details of) and he still asked questions that were unanswerable. people practically clapped when doebley came back. luckily, everyone did poorly so the curve was generous

the absolute worst. mumbled his way through complicated material. stuffed way too to much information into each lecture. his exam asked the tiniest details and nothing about general principles. even the ta's were blindsighted by what he asked on his exam. stay. away.

He was better than William Engels, but not by much.  He goes way, way too fast and his slides have a mind-blast of information on them.  He skips over much of the information presented, and then expects you to know it in the end.  If I hadn't had an index card to use for the exams... ugh, this class sucked.

This class is pure torture, I felt as though I was a prisoner of Azkaban with the genetics dementors sucking the life from my body everyday of the semester.  Don't take this class unless it is a requirement. The grading is unfair on the homework.  I worked with my friend, wrote the same answers and got 10% less on every one. Bullsh*t. Waste of time
Prof. Laughton is very knowledgeable in molecular genetics and it shows. He is a good lecturer although the powerpoint slides are not great. Exam was pretty straight forward but did contain specifics

First semester with this course, put in the time & effort to teach a subject he is clearly very knowledgeable about & fascinated with. Genuine interest in student input, & will take suggestions, provided he agrees with them. Does have rather optimistic assumptions regarding student background with the subject. Smart guy, good instructor.

Tough class in general, any prof will be. Better than the 1st prof, but still almost impossible to sit through a whole lecture w/o daydreaming or falling asleep. Exams are nitpicky & ask teeny tiny details. Study for days and you're not getting an A. Slides are pretty clear & easy to understand when you review them. Not horrible, I guess.

Has walked us through basic genetics, and his expectations never seem too high as to our understanding (ie: when things are too difficult, he can be easily prompted to explain).  He can be unclear at times, but in general makes good use of teaching aids to further his point.
Very confusing, if you have no prior knowledge of genetics I'd highly recommend avoiding any of his classes. Assumes that students know much more than they should.
Horrible...talks more about his research than what is on the exams.
